I wonder if the fabella is technically a vestigial bone that went out of use an extremely long time ago, hence why it is so small and not present in every person. It could've developed to stabilize our knee joints when we started to walk upright. Once we developed better, more effective adaptations that help us walk without bending our knees backwards, the bone became vestigial. That would've been so long ago that it's barely a remnant now, a tiny bean sized nub not even present in the majority of the population.

Auricular muscles: anterior, oblique & posterior auricular muscles, innervated by cranial nerve VII, which is the facial nerve.
Fabella: small sesamoid bone, part of the distal tendon of the gastrocnemius muscle posterior to the lateral condyle of the femur.
Lacrimal puncta: also known as the lateral points are two small openings at the top of the medial lacrimal papillae on the lower eyelids.

Not sure why you'd think these are all that unusual, any undergraduate Anatomy & Physiology class will mention them at some point.

My lacrimal puncta was blocked at birth (idk which eye or if both) and my mom constantly had to massage it/them to get it to drain. I can't make my ears visibly move (much), but I can definitely flex some muscles back there on command—the thing I can't do is reliably relax them on command, sometimes they'll flex on their own, especially if there's sound. If I had a wheelchair tied to those I'd be scared for my life.

I have a small hole in between my nose and my eye, right where an incision would be made to drain the lachrymal duct. But there's no documentation that I've ever had that surgery, and my mom knows that I never did. I've had it since I could remember, now 19. It's several millimeters deep, and I can easily stick a safety pin in it to clean it out. Skin never attempts to grow over it, and it gets filled with gunk, like a black head. None of my doctors know what it is, and research has shown nothing.
